ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

SINGAPORE BROADCASTING AUTHORITY INTERNET CONTENT GUIDELINES


    1. Assoc. Prof Walter Woon asked the Minister for Information and the Arts what is the rationale for paragraph 4(d) of the Singapore Broadcasting Authority Internet Content Guidelines which states that any matter that tends to "bring the Government into hatred or contempt, or which excites disaffection against the Government" shall not be allowed.

     The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Information and the Arts (Encik Mohamad Maidin B P M) (for the Minister for Information and the Arts): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Singapore Broadcasting Authority (SBA) Internet Content Guidelines help to set a minimum standard of conduct and community values in the parts of cyberspace that affect Singapore. They cover three key areas - (1) Public Morals, (2) Racial and Religious Harmony, and (3) Public Security and National Defence. The guidelines are drawn from the existing laws of Singapore. Paragraph 4(d) of the guidelines, which states that any matter that tends to "bring the Government into hatred or contempt, or which excites disaffection against the Government, shall not be allowed", comes under the area of Public Security and National Defence. It is based on the formulation found in the Sedition Act which has been in place since 1938. The purpose is to outlaw any seditious act, speech, words or publication.

    We have repeated these words from the Sedition Act in the Internet guidelines to remind Internet users that the Sedition Act apply as much in cyberspace as it does outside it.

     Assoc. Prof. Walter Woon (Nominated Member): Sir, will the hon. Parliamentary Secretary say who will make the decision as to whether any website or posting is politically unacceptable?

Column: 860



     Encik Mohamad Maidin B P M: Sir, normally the Singapore Broadcasting Authority will be the authority in charge of overseeing all activities, ie, whether or not it comes under the Sedition Act, whether it is political in nature or it promotes racial hatred and other commentaries. This matter will then be taken up and we will consult the Attorney-General's Chambers for advice as to whether it contravenes our laws or not.

     Assoc. Prof. Walter Woon: Sir, I do not believe the Parliamentary Secretary has actually answered my question. We are not talking about committing an offence. We are talking about who is going to make the decision as to whether or not a website should be banned or a posting should be taken off. Who in the SBA? Is there a committee or is it a single person? Is there going to be a group of persons?

     Encik Mohamad Maidin B P M: Sir, in the end, it is the Minister who has the power to decide. But before that, we also have the National Internet Advisory Committee which comprises people from the industry and community leaders from various groups who will look into all problems connected with Internet usage in Singapore. It will look into whether serious offences had taken place and recommend whether action should be taken by the Ministry.

     Assoc. Prof. Walter Woon: Will there be any appeal procedure if, for example, it is determined that a particular website is political and therefore should not be allowed? Will there be an appeal procedure or will the decision be final?

     Encik Mohamad Maidin B P M: Sir, a website that is political in nature is not disallowed. In fact, we have regulations which require political websites to at least register their editors or owners, and they are allowed to operate. The reason why we register them is to ensure some accountability and responsibility as we promote political discussion on the Net.

     Assoc. Prof. Walter Woon: Sir, will the Parliamentary Secretary then confirm that

Column: 861

it is not the Government's intention to curtail discussion and free expression on the Internet?

     Encik Mohamad Maidin B P M: Sir, I can say yes, it is not our intention at all to curtail political discussions on the Internet. Maybe I will draw the Member's attention to some parts of the Sedition Act which allow exceptions to be made, ie, discussions which affect the Government but they were intended for good reasons. In other words, they found something which they thought it necessary to be discussed, reviewed and debated because certain activities in the state may not be good for Singaporeans. If the intention is good, I think the Government will not stop such discussions.

    In fact, the reason why we have provided certain laws is to ensure more transparency. People who use the Net would want to be sure that there is a level playing field with certain regulations to protect the innocent. There have been some developments but they are still relatively new. MITA will continue to monitor the situation and try to improve on our regulations either by tightening or loosening them up. These methods will be monitored continuously as the Internet continues to grow in our country.

     Assoc. Prof. Walter Woon: For the avoidance of doubt, will the Parliamentary Secretary then confirm that Singaporeans are entitled to disagree with the Government and to say so freely?

     Encik Mohamad Maidin B P M: I say yes, Sir.
LAND ACQUISITION BY GOVERNMENT


    2. Mr John De Payva asked the Minister for Law whether the Government acquires land for as little as $1.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Law (Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee) (for the Minister for Law): Sir, as a general rule, the Government does not acquire land for $1. However, there are some special circumstances where it does so. These are:

Column: 862



    (a) firstly, where the land is that part of a site that has been set aside for public purposes such as roads or drainage reserves, as required under the planning approval given for the development of the site;

    (b) secondly, where the land is an odd piece which cannot be developed on its own and is designated for road or drainage reserves, such as backlanes, spray corners and public access roads; or

    (c) thirdly, where the land has been sub-leased by the owner for a long tenure like 999 years. In such a case, the sub-lessee would be paid the full statutory compensation. The owner is paid only the compensation for his nominal reversionary interest in the land, that is, his residual interest at the end of the sub-lease.

     Dr Ker Sin Tze (Aljunied GRC): Sir, is the Senior Parliamentary Secretary aware that in the last issue of The New Democrat, the SDP had criticised the Government for acquiring land as low as $1?

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, this is typical of the SDP in trying to distort and mislead the people. It made it out that valuable plots of land were unjustifiably acquired at $1. Sir, I have explained the situation. In any particular case where an aggrieved owner feels that the land has greater value, say, that it has potential for independent development, there is an avenue of appeal under the Land Acquisition Act.
SALE OF GOODS (AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.
12.40 pm

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Law (Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee): Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    The United Kingdom's Sale of Goods Act 1979 is part of our laws being applicable by virtue of the Application of English Law Act (Cap. 7A).

Column: 863



    In the United Kingdom, changes have been made to the Sale of Goods Act 1979 by the Sale and Supply of Goods Act 1994 and by the Sale of Goods (Amendment) Act 1995.

    Both the Attorney-General and the Law Reform Committee of the Singapore Academy of Law have considered these changes and have recommended that our Sale of Goods Act be similarly amended. The Law Society also commends these amendments as they reflect the changing needs of consumers.

    Sir, the Bill therefore seeks to incorporate the relevant changes in our Sale of Goods Act. The amendments will bring our domestic commercial laws up to date with developments in the United Kingdom. Let me go through the main amendments.

    First, under the existing section 14 of the Sale of Goods Act, there is an implied condition in every contract for the sale of goods that the goods are of merchantable quality. The expression "merchantable quality" is outmoded and inappropriate, especially in the context of a consumer transaction. Its definition also emphasises too much the concept of fitness for purpose of the goods.

    Hence, the Bill replaces the implied conditions of merchantable quality with that of "satisfactory quality". This reformulated implied condition is intended to apply to all contracts for the sale of goods where the seller sells in the course of business. Whether goods are of "satisfactory quality" will be determined by reference, not only to fitness for purpose, but also to various other factors such as appearance and finish, freedom from minor defects, durability and safety for use.

    Secondly, the implied terms in the existing sections 13, 14 and 15 of the Sale of Goods Act are classified as "conditions". This gives a buyer an unrestricted right to reject the goods and treat the contract as repudiated if there is a breach of one of these terms, unless the buyer is deemed to have accepted the goods under the Act.

Column: 864



    The status quo will be preserved where consumers are concerned. For non-consumers, the law will be amended such that if the breach is so slight that it would be unreasonable for the buyer to reject the goods and treat the contract as repudiated, he will not be able to do so but will instead be able to pursue any other remedy against the seller, including the recovery of damages.

    Thirdly, under the existing law, property in the goods cannot pass to the buyer until the goods are ascertained. The buyer is therefore exposed to the risk of the seller's insolvency and if the price has been paid, may lose both the price and the goods.

    The amendments remedy this situation by enabling the pre-paying buyer to become an owner in common of the bulk and by laying down the legal implications of this relationship. This will give the pre-paying buyer a proprietary interest which he can enforce in the event of the seller's insolvency.

    Finally, Sir, the Bill clarifies the law relating to the acceptance of goods by a buyer. Under the present law, if a buyer accepts some of the goods sold to him he will be treated as if he had accepted them all. The amendments made by the Bill will enable the buyer to accept all the goods which conform to the terms of the contract and reject all the goods that do not, or to accept the conforming goods and some of the non-conforming goods and reject the rest.

    Sir, the amendments also make it clear that a buyer who asks for goods to be repaired, or agrees to their repair, will not be deemed to have accepted them merely because of his request or agreement, and that a buyer will not be deemed to have accepted the goods merely because he sub-sells them and delivers them to another person, or disposes of them in some other way.

    Sir, these changes are not intended to bring about any major shift in the balance of rights and obligations as between a buyer and a seller of goods. They are to update and clarify the law relating to the sale of goods so as to benefit buyers and sellers alike.

Column: 865



    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Bill accordingly read a Second time and committed to a Committee of the whole House.

    The House immediately resolved itself into a Committee on the Bill. - [Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee].

    Bill considered in Committee; reported without amendment; read a Third time and passed.

SUPPLY OF GOODS (AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Law (Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Sir, this Bill is closely related to the Sale of Goods (Amendment) Bill, which we have just dealt with.

    By virtue of the Application of English Law Act (Cap. 7A), Parts I and III of the United Kingdom's Supply of Goods and Services Act 1982 and Parts I and III of the United Kingdom's Unfair Contract Terms Act 1977 are applicable in Singapore. Like the United Kingdom's Sale of Goods Act 1979, these enactments are reprinted in our Revised Edition of Statutes as part of our legislation.

    Sir, in the United Kingdom, changes were made to Parts I and III of the Supply of Goods and Services Act 1982 by the Sale and Supply of Goods Act 1994.

    Again, both the Attorney-General and the Law Reform Committee of the Singapore Academy of Law have considered these changes and have recommended that our Supply of Goods Act be similarly amended. As such, this Bill seeks to incorporate the relevant changes in our Supply of Goods Act.

    As in the case of contracts for the sale of goods, the new reformulated implied condition of "satisfactory quality" will replace the existing implied condition of merchantable quality in all contracts for the transfer of goods and contracts for the hire of goods.

Column: 866



    Also, where there has been a breach of contract by a transferor or bailor towards a non-consumer transferee or bailee and the breach is so slight that it would be unreasonable for the transferee or bailee to reject the goods and repudiate the contract, the transferee or bailee will not be allowed to do so but he will be able to pursue any other remedy including the recovery of damages.

    Finally, the Bill also incorporates in our Unfair Contract Terms Act an amendment similar to that made by the UK's Supply of Goods Act 1982 to Part I of her Unfair Contract Terms Act 1977.

    This amendment provides that, in a case where the possession or ownership of goods passes under or pursuant to a contract not governed by the law of sale of goods or hire-purchase, liability for breach of the obligations arising under section 2 of the Supply of Goods Act cannot be excluded or restricted by reference to any contract terms which purport to exclude or restrict liability for breach of obligation arising by implication of law from the nature of the contract.

    Sir, again, may I say that these changes are not intended to bring about any major shift in the balance of rights and obligations as between a buyer and a supplier of goods but to update and clarify the law relating to the supply of goods so as to benefit buyers and suppliers alike.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Bill accordingly read a Second time and committed to a Committee of the whole House.

    The House immediately resolved itself into a Committee on the Bill. - [Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee].

    Bill considered in Committee; reported without amendment, read a Third time and passed.

COST REVIEW COMMITTEE REPORT
(Motion)


     Mr Loh Meng See (Kampong Glam GRC): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    *That this House endorses the conclusions of the Cost Review Committee contained in Misc 4 of 1996,

Column: 867

and calls on the Government to accept the recommendations to contain rises in the cost of living and to assist the poor and the elderly.

    Sir, the Cost Review Committee has done very good work. The findings and recommendations contained in the CRC Report are comprehensive, straightforward and down-to-earth. The Committee was represented by academics, businessmen, journalists and trade unionists. They were ably supported by the officials of different Government Ministries.

    The task of the CRC was not easy. They had the most unpleasant meeting with the Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) and Pertubuhan Kebangsaan Melayu Singapura (PKMS). The meeting was marred by bad manners, hostile attitudes and irresponsible behaviour displayed by the two opposition parties. Fortunately, the CRC meetings with the other organisations, like the Consumers Association of Singapore, Emporium Holdings and NTUC Fairprice were more sober and fruitful.

    It was obvious that Dr Chee Soon Juan and his group were out to confuse and mislead the public with distortions. Dr Chee has the habit of making wild and unfounded allegations. He would bring up isolated cases and personal anecdotes and treat them as though they are rampant in Singapore. He should know better that one swallow does not make a summer. It is true that prices and costs have risen but the increases were by no means "phenomenal" as exaggerated by SDP and PKMS. The vast majority of Singaporeans are enjoying higher standards of living and better lifestyles than before.

    Dr Chee is not known to see issues in perspective and in the context of the overall environment. Having raised the issues, he is not interested in seeing them through to their logical conclusions. The CRC has been steadfast in its work. It did not set out to work for the sake of the opposition parties. The members used their time and expertise in the interest of Singapore and Singaporeans.

Column: 868



    For the SDP and PKMS to allege that the cost of living represented by the Consumer Price Index was hidden from the public through a "statistical massage of numbers" was a grave affront to all Members of Parliament. Every year, Parliament debates the Government budget of expenditure. Are they suggesting that we MPs are being misled? And worse still, Parliament is insinuated as perpetuating the misrepresentation of official statistics. I wonder what the Opposition Members of Parliament have got to say of these accusations. I am glad that the CRC in making its independent and objective evaluation has once again re-affirmed the integrity of Singapore's statistical system and the consistency and soundness of the Consumer Price Index.

    The MP for Hougang, Mr Low Thia Khiang, has chosen to stay away from this year's CRC deliberations. I think Mr Low wanted to avoid having to agree with the findings of the CRC. He would not want to be put in the awkward position as an Opposition MP. Nevertheless, at the Select Committee on Health Care Subsidy of Government Polyclinics and Public Hospitals, Mr Low had praised the work of the Auditor-General. After reading the CRC Report, would Mr Low also commend the work of the Chief Statistician this time? Perhaps Mr Low would like to give his view to this House on the work of the Chief Statistician and the Department of Statistics.

    As Chairman of GPC for Health, I am naturally interested in the findings and recommendations of the CRC on health care issues. As we discuss the cost issues on health care, it is important for us to recognise and acknowledge that Singapore has one of the best health care systems in the world. Even then, we should not stop in making further improvements. Perhaps, we can now fine-tune our health care delivery system so that individual Singaporeans can be given the best possible care befitting his individual circumstances and medical conditions.

    The Health Ministry has recently pledged to intensify the efforts on financial counselling to patients on

Column: 869

admission to hospitals. The Ministry has also agreed to remove all unnecessary red-tapes that may cause inconvenience to the patients and their families. This firm commitment and action would lead to even better quality service in the public hospitals and Government polyclinics.

    Sir, there are some patients, because of their chronic conditions, can ill-afford to pay cash of a couple of hundreds of dollars a month for their long-term medications. I join the CRC in urging the Health Ministry to extend the use of Medisave savings for some outpatient medical tests and treatment that are necessary to maintain the health status of patients, particularly elderly patients, and to prevent complications.

    Recently, I visited the Alexandra Hospital. I am very impressed by the excellent facilities provided at that Government hospital. Alexandra Hospital has very good subsidised B2 and C class wards to look after the elderly patients. They have the Geriatric Centre to cater to the special medical conditions and needs of the elderly patients. More publicity should be given to encourage Singaporeans to use the medical facilities at Alexandra Hospital which is relatively cheaper compared to the other restructured hospitals like SGH and NUH.

    It would appear that the opt-in system for MediShield coverage for dependent children did not work. Generally, healthy people pay little heed to the need to sign up for medical insurance until it is too late. As the response to MediShield protection for dependent children is poor, with only 25% being covered, the Health Ministry should change the opt-in system to an opt-out system for the benefit of our young children and their families.

    I share the concern of the CRC that a quarter of the elderly Singaporeans over 60 years old have opted out of MediShield coverage when one would have thought that they need the insurance coverage most. This matter needs closer study by the Health Ministry to entice the elderly to cover themselves under MediShield which is actually good for them. The financial burden can be very heavy when stricken

Column: 870

with a catastrophic illness. I wonder if this is related to their inability to use CPF savings to pay for MediShield premium when they are retired and no longer contributing to CPF. The suggestion of the CRC to work out a personal MediShield endowment account to keep the MediShield insurance coverage alive is an interesting one.

    Sir, on 13th January 1994, when moving the motion of thanks to the President for his Speech to Parliament, I had raised the subject of reverse mortgage to help the elderly in their living expenses. The CRC has recommended, "that reverse mortgages be made available to the elderly to benefit from the rise in the property values over the years." The HDB should seriously consider how a reverse mortgage scheme could be implemented to help the elderly who are in need without jeopardising the virtues and values of the strong traditional family-support system.

    The cooperative movement based on the principles of thrift and self-help has worked successfully in Singapore. The cooperative spirit should be extended to areas that can provide tangible benefits to Singaporeans. I support the CRC's call to the Government to facilitate the setting up of housing cooperatives to build private properties at lower cost and pass back the savings to the buyers who are members of the cooperative.

    In preparing for the aging population, the NTUC has mooted the idea of building retirement villages within HDB housing estates so that the elderly can continue to stay in the community. The retirement village is good for those who choose and can afford to live in these retirement villages.

    Sir, for the less fortunate elderly, I wish to suggest that the HDB redesign and reconfigure the present 1-room rental flats provided for aged singles. We should make more economical use of the space and reduce the need of building more nursing homes in the future. At certain floors of HDB blocks, common facilities can be provided. We can encourage voluntary welfare organisations to adopt

Column: 871

and provide services to the frail and the aged to live independently in these dormitory-type accommodation. It is not only the money that matters but also the physical help and the ability to socialise with others are as much needed by this growing segment of our population.

    As Singapore continues to progress and grow, more and more Singaporeans will enjoy the fruits of the country's success. Unfortunately, the rewards are not evenly distributed. Those with the right skills and talents will be better off. The challenge for us is to ensure that Singaporeans continue to have good jobs and good salaries. We have to learn to be self-reliant and to live within our means. We have to recognise that life is full of ups and downs. There will be good years and not so good years. We should not envy others who are better off than us.

    The cost of living issues raised by the opposition parties are out to divide our people. They fan the emotions of our people. They play up the weak nature of people, to be envious of others. This will break down the social fabric of our society. This will work against our national interest and objective in making our people work together, be united and live in peace and harmony. For those Singaporeans who are well off, they should not flaunt their wealth. The wealthy should not be so arrogant as to look down upon the poor, weak and helpless. The rich must help the poor and the strong for the weak. This makes for a compassionate and gracious society. We must keep the trust between our leaders and our citizens.

    As we move into the new millennium, there are many countries in the region wanting to catch up with Singapore. If we were to let down our guard and go for soft options, we do so at our own peril, then we deserve the bad consequences.

    Sir, I have faith in the Singaporean. We are a small country but a rich people seeking justice and righteousness, both in spirit and in truth. I have no doubt that together we can overcome the external

Column: 872

     3. Folly of jumping to conclusions

    The next lesson, Sir, I would like to highlight is the danger of jumping to conclusions. That may be the only exercise that some people in Singapore

Column: 898

choose to take. However, most of us would agree on the need to be more circumspect in our judgment.

    We cannot necessarily conclude that prices have risen "phenomenally" just because household spending was reported to have risen by 76% during the period under consideration. We need to explore further and dig deeper to find out the real reasons for this rise in spending. Fortunately, the Report of the CRC has put matters into perspective. We understand better why there has been a 76% rise in spending. In fact, this increase attests to our phenomenal economic success as a nation. After all, we are the ninth richest country in the world with a standard of living which is second to Japan in this region. A small increase in household spending would suggest that we have yet to arrive in the "economic" sense. Also, Singapore's quick economic climb should have been accompanied by an even higher percentage of household spending but for the moderating influence of a strong Singapore dollar that curbed the price of many goods.

     4. The lesson on the disadvantaged

    The fact that increased spending has allowed many of us to purchase better quality goods and services and improve our standard of living must not blind us to the reality that some of our brothers and sisters in Singapore may be economically less fortunate than us. These people are adversely affected by the general increase in the cost of living. They should remind

us that we need to increase the redistribution of wealth in the form of subsidised services for the needy, the poor and the elderly. These groups need both our support and our resources to improve their standard of living.

The CRC, as this view goes, is therefore not really independent and cannot be expected to criticise the Government. Most importantly, the general election is around the corner.

    In my view, there is undoubtedly a political element in the reconvening of the Cost Review Committee. The issue of the rising cost of living in Singapore has once again become a hot domestic issue. SDP and PKMS have politicised this by making the claim that the rise in the cost of living has been no less than phenomenal and that there has been a statistical massage of the numbers. However, the fact that this issue has become politicised makes it no less an issue of sufficient importance. It therefore merits serious consideration with or without its politicisation. It affects the life of many Singaporeans, every Singaporean.

Discount the more overtly political elements, if you will, but I would urge Singaporeans not to throw the baby out along with the bath water. Many of the recommendations made by the CRC are good, sensible ones which could genuinely help in keeping costs down.

    The second theme is one which has been lurking beneath the surface and that is the question: to what extent is the Government to be blamed for the rise in the cost of living? I believe that the first and most important factor accounting for the rise in the cost of living in the 1990s is the booming economy. The economy grew at 8.9% per year from 1992 to 1995. With such buoyant demand and constraints in supply, wages increased by 7.1% and property prices also rose. Wage and rental costs have worked their way into the pricing of goods and services, particularly of domestic services. For example, a bowl of noodles is more expensive and has less ingredients in it now than even five years ago. Were it not for the fact that the Singapore dollar appreciated during this period, inflation would have been even higher than what it has been.

    Does this mean therefore that Government policy had no part to play at all in the rise in prices? I do not think so. Certain Government policies have had the effect of contributing towards an increase in demand and hence a rise in prices. For example, where HDB resale flats are

Column: 909

concerned, the sharp rise in prices in 1993 is clearly associated with the easing of the HDB mortgage loan scheme from 80% of 1984 posted prices to 80% of market value. The reverse has also been experienced with the stricter property market regulations introduced in May this year.

    There is another factor. This is the Government's philosophy of pricing public sector goods and services. In essence, this could be summarised as market rates, wherever possible, with subsidies for essential services based on a sliding scale. Take, land, for example. Government land sales are now by tender in the open market. Land acquired under the Land Acquisition Act used to be compensated at historical prices which bore no relation to reality. But now compensation for land is much closer to market rates. The principle of market rate valuation plus the rise in land prices in a booming economy could be one factor while the land cost index for HDB housing rose by 24.9% per year during 1992 to 1995. This in turn was one of the two major reasons for the price increases of HDB flats during the period.

    In the area of essential social services, such as health, housing and education, the Government still grants subsidies but on a sliding scale. C class wards have a subsidy rate of 80%; B2 wards, 65%; B1 wards, 20% and A class, none at all. Similarly, it used to be that the subsidy rate for 3- and 4-room HDB flats was about 30% of the total development cost, while that for 5-room and Executive flats was about 10%. More recently, it was announced that there would be a price guarantee for 3- and 4-room HDB flats so that at least 90% and 70% respectively of Singaporean households would be able to pay their monthly mortgages entirely out of their CPF.

    Similarly, subsidies in education are nearly 100% for primary, secondary, junior college and vocational education, while it is 78% for university education. What this meant was that where subsidy rates were higher than the target levels, the reduction in the actual subsidy rates contributed towards price increases in the relevant services. This included university tuition

Column: 910

fees that Mr Chay Wai Chuen just referred to and A and B1 hospital ward charges. It is also instructive that while the price of a 4-room Model A HDB flat increased by an average annual rate of 5.4% between 1992 and 1995, that for 5-room and Executive flats increased by 10% and 11.2%, respectively, about double that of the annual increase of 4-room Model A HDB flats.

    Does this mean then that the Goverment system of pricing is no good and should be changed? One must consider that the other side of the coin is that while subsidies have been reduced, so have taxes. The corporate tax rate is now 26% while the highest marginal personal income tax rate is 28%, relatively low by international standards. We do not have large budget deficits because of subsidies which are difficult to control. I believe that market rate pricing of Government services is the most efficient system available to allocate scarce resources.

    I also support the Goverment's policy of continued subsidies in order to make basic services affordable, particularly for the poor and the needy. Dr Soin has elaborated at length on the need for such affordability, particularly in the case where for the poor and the needy, they need these subsidies in order to make basic services affordable. However, I do not support subsidies for what can be considered more luxurious accommodation, such as Executive Condominiums. I would also urge Government agencies, statutory boards and corporatised agencies to think twice, perhaps more than twice, before increasing Government fees and charges. The multiplier effects are actually quite considerable when these fees and charges are raised. Price increases should be considered as a measure of last resort, not just to maintain profits and surpluses.

    The third theme is that accompanying Singapore's rapid economic growth has been equally rapid changes in norms, expectations and lifestyles. For example, 65% of first-time applicants for HDB flats opted for 5-room and Executive flats in 1995 compared to 47% in 1992. In other words, in just three years, there has been

Column: 911

a change of 18 percentage points in terms of the numbers of first-time applicants who opted for 5-room and Executive flats. Why do norms in Singapore have to change so rapidly? If 3- or 4-room HDB flats were good enough for our parents and even for us when we were growing up, why are they no longer good enough for the present generation now? Have some of us gotten on to the treadmill of rising norms only to face the frustration of unfulfilled expectations?

    To summarise, the basics are still affordable in Singapore, 3- and 4-room HDB flats, primary and secondary school education, bus fares. It would be hard put to say that these are beyond the reach even of the majority of Singaporeans regardless of income levels. However, A class and private hospital health care, private property, cars, these are expensive in a thriving city state located in a booming Asian region. It is ultimately a lifestyle choice and what one can afford. Take, air travel, for example. There is really no necessity to opt for first-class or even business class. Economy class gets you to your destination in exactly the same time on the same plane.

my union members who work in bookshops that sell such books, and I was told that the errors are still there. On the one hand, Dr Chee says, "I am sorry. I am only human. I can also make mistakes." On the other hand, he allows the mistakes to remain in the books being sold. Where is his integrity?

Column: 915

food. These days when husbands and wives work, eating out has become more prevalent. But if they eat out, they must be prepared to pay more because our hawkers too need increases in income year after year.

    The CRC has done a good job. It has been thorough in assessing the situation. It has debunked the wild claims of the SDP. It has shown that we have an effective system of government backed by various social organisations. Lower-income workers need not despair. There are avenues for them to rise if they are prepared to go for training and retraining. There are bursaries. There are scholarship awards for children of lower-income workers. for anything and everything that we want. Some things come easier than others, but the most desirable things require much more effort. And not everyone attains them. extensively reported in all our newspapers, on television and on radio, the SDP continues to purvey misinformation.

Without comment, they produced the charts and from the charts, you will know that the cost of secondary school education and junior college education has risen over the years by several thousand dollars per year per child, and increasing over time. The impression of such a publication without comment is to convey the impression that parents are paying more for sending their children to secondary school or to junior college. But the truth is that the fees have not been changed for the last few years.

So the parents continue to pay a nominal sum, not the thousands of dollars which the New Democrat tries to purvey.

    These are examples in one issue of the New Democrat. Mr John De Payva has mentioned something else, that of Ministers' pay. All these are clear examples of misinformation. The SDP continues to sell the New Democrat freely in Singapore. Mr John De Payva asked a question: why is it that publications which contain errors and misinformation are still being allowed to be sold in Singapore? In case anybody in Singapore or anywhere else in the world thinks there is no freedom of expression in Singapore, why is this still continuing in Singapore?

    I think Mr Low Thia Khiang had learnt from the previous sitting of the Cost Review Committee and he knows how difficult it is to argue against the full facts and therefore also declined to participate in the Committee this time. He probably prefers the more comfortable position of asking questions rather than to be involved in getting to the root of the issues. Again, today, of course, he has taken the opportunity to ask some questions. He tries to imply that the Cost Review Committee's explanation about people buying better goods and employing maids as blaming the people for the rise in the cost of living. I think this is unfair and my colleague, Dr Ow Chin Hock, had rightfully rebutted the point immediately. We in the Committee had been trying to establish what had caused the increase in spending and to explain to the people who do not understand why the expenditures have gone up. We are not blaming anybody. We are not blaming the public for the rise in the cost of living.

    I think it is a pity that Mr Low did not participate in the Committee, because he would have learnt a lot more in this second session of the Cost Review Committee. If he wishes to continue to play a constructive role in political debate in Singapore, he would have gained a better understanding of the issues at hand. I dare say that he would have learnt a few lessons in economics. He would

Column: 919

also have learnt what are the factors underpinning Singapore's growth over the years. He missed the opportunity.

    After 10 meetings spanning over 50 hours, the Cost Review Committee's conclusions and recommendations are contained in the Report. Our findings are there. Members have referred to them and commented on them and I would not repeat. But the Report accounts for why people feel that the cost of living has risen even sharply. This feeling is fueled particularly by the rise of high profile items - housing, health care and certain domestic services. These high profile items mask the general rise in the standard of living.

    On housing, the CRC found that HDB selling prices are still affordable. More people are buying bigger flats, which means that purchasing power has, in fact, risen because wages have risen. At a public hearing, the HDB reaffirmed that HDB flats will be kept affordable.

    The resale market prices of HDB flats, however, had gone up. We found that it was not due to HDB raising prices and so pushing up prices on the resale market. Instead, it was due to other factors, such as infrastructure improvements or the Main Upgrading Programme. The major factor in the past few years, however, has been "easy credit". The HDB had liberalised, usually in response to public requests, including requests from Members of Parliament, but each time credit was eased, the resale prices went up! Liberalisation caused an increase in demand, but without a similar increase in supply, the prices rose. It is a demonstration of the fundamental law of economics! In the Report on page 69, Chart 4-2, this is clearly shown. This easy credit, coupled with what Dr Lee Tsao Yuan described earlier about the booming economy and the rise in incomes, has made the cost of housing the way they were in the last few years.

    As the HDB resale prices rose, some cashed in, and used the capital gains to buy private property. Some cashed in and bought, again from the HDB, and pocketed

Column: 920

the cash. Others used it to upgrade to private property. This, plus easy credit again, led to the rise in private property prices. As some people made quick money on the property market, more people jumped in. In such a situation, if credit is not tightened, then the only other lever to pull is supply. For quite some time the Ministry of National Development regularly announced that supply was coming and that it would be increased if there was demand. But there is a time-lag between announcement of supply and actual supply coming on to the market. Finally, the lever which had an immediate impact, the tightening of credit, was pulled. This was the 14th May measures. Clearly, they are effective because demand has shrunk. We should be careful in future when controlling the levers on credit. You loosen the controls too much, the prices will rise sharply. You tighten the controls too much, there will be a crash in prices. So whoever is controlling the lever has got to move very cautiously and carefully.

    The Cost Review Committee has urged Singaporeans to be prudent in their spending. A house is a desirable item, but one should spend within one's means. We should not assume that housing prices are on a one-way upward escalator. It is a roller-coaster as well. There was a crash in housing prices in the 1970s. I was one of those caught in it. There was another crash in the 1980s. These experiences should teach us to be prudent and to beware the trap of easy credit. Each time I see or hear a bank advertising easy credit, I wonder why there is not a law against it.

    The other sensitive cost item is hospital expenses. The basic reasons for the rise in medical expenses are wage costs, advance in medical knowledge, and a shift to higher class wards, or to private hospitals. The Government has anticipated this rise, and has therefore devised the Medisave, MediShield and Medifund schemes. Unfortunately, there is a general

Column: 921

lack of understanding by the people, so people worry more than they need to. More so, when procedures in hospitals give the impression that money comes first.

    People do not understand various Government policies. This is a point which Dr Soin mentioned. Is it due to the loss of the art of communication or is it due to people not listening? I do not know the true reasons, but I know that when it comes to medical treatment, people will not bother with MediShield or Medifund until they go to hospital and find that there are high bills to pay. It is only then that they will try to find out how the expenses can be met. Having said that, I think it is true today that we have many policies which are for the benefit of the people which are complex and even, if I may say so, Members of Parliament will find difficulty to explain. the hawker food business, a change from the labour-intensive methods currently employed, very soon our hawker food will cost more than the Western import, hamburgers. I am glad to say that restructuring of the hawker food business has been going on, though a bit slowly, over the last few years.
